awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Nonconvex Optimization for High-Dimensional Signal Estimation: Theory and Fast Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
High-dimensional signal estimation plays fundamental roles in various engineering and science applications, such as medical imaging, video and network surveillance. Estimation procedures that maintain both statistical and computational efficacy are of great practical value, which translate into desiderata such as less time patients need to spend in a medical scanner, faster response to cyber attacks, and capabilities to handle very large datasets. While a lot of signal estimation tasks are naturally formulated as nonconvex optimization problems, existing results for nonconvex methods have several fundamental limitations, and the current state of the art is still limited in terms of when, why and which nonconvex approaches are effective for a given problem. The goal of this research program is to significantly deepen and broaden the understanding and applications of nonconvex optimization for high-dimensional signal estimation.

In this project, the investigators will study high-dimensional signal estimation via direct optimization of nonconvex, and potentially nonsmooth, loss functions, without resorting to convex relaxation. This research will explore geometric structures shared by nonconvex functions commonly encountered in signal estimation, and study the fundamental roles these structures play in determining the algorithmic convergence. These results will then be exploited as guidelines to develop fast and provably correct algorithms for estimating high-dimensional signals with physically induced structures and under streaming data observations. Specifically, the research program consists of three major thrusts: (1) understanding the geometric structures of important classes of nonconvex loss surfaces, and characterizing their impact on the convergence of optimization algorithms; (2) developing fast algorithms and the associated theory for the recovery of structured low-rank matrices; (3) designing new online algorithms that are time and space efficient under a streaming setting, with the capability of detecting and tracking the time-varying signals of interest.

por.por_cntn:
Many problems in data science involve extracting from a large dataset some form useful information, often represented by a signal with many variables. This task, called high-dimensional signal estimation, is of fundamental importance in many engineering and science applications including medical imaging, video and network surveillance. It is crucial in practical applications to develop estimation methods that are both statistically efficient (e.g., more accurate results with patients spending less time in a medical scanner) and computationally efficient (e.g., being able to handle massive datasets, faster response to cyber attacks). Many important signal estimation tasks involve nonconvex optimization, which is a class of challenge-to-solve optimization problems. Existing nonconvex methods are limited by their high computational cost, or the lack of understanding of when, why and which methods are effective for a given problem.

In this project, the investigators significantly deepen and broaden the understanding and applications of nonconvex optimization for high-dimensional signal estimation. Instead of using the common approach of convex relaxation, the project studies direct optimization of nonconvex loss functions. The project characterizes the geometric structures shared by nonconvex functions commonly encountered in signal estimation, and shows that the geometric structures are often benign despite nonconvexity. These benign structures are then shown to induce rapid convergence of algorithmic procedures for solving nonconvex optimization problems. Leveraging this interplay between geometry and convergence, the investigators rigorously establish that many low-complexity algorithms, such as spectral and first-order gradient-based methods, are provably efficient for a broad class of nonconvex signal estimation problems. These results apply to concrete problems such as clustering, low-rank matrix estimation, subspace estimation, and many others. Importantly, these methods are practically efficient and enjoy rigorous theoretical performance guarantees.

This project provides training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students with diverse backgrounds, and supports outreach activities,  mentorship activities and course developments. Research outcomes are broadly disseminated through journal papers, seminar and conference presentations, and survey articles.
